body_text.text: In December 2019 a new coronavirus disease (COVID-19) was identified in Wuhan, China. 1 By 26 th March 2020, over 450,000 confirmed cases, and over 20,000 deaths across 172 countries had 23 occured. 1 While diverse age groups can experience the severe consequences of COVID-19, the virus 24 has the most detrimental impact on ageing adults over 65. 2 Data from the United States of America 25 COVID-19, while 4 to 11 percent of adults between 65 and 84 years of age die. 2 Furthermore, 27 between 11 and 27 percent of those over 85 die. 2 28

Countries with ageing populations such as Australia have reason to be concerned. Currently, 17.7 29 percent of people in Australia have a disability and 15.9 percent are over the age of 65 (ABS, 2019). 3 30

The first four cases of COVID-19 were confirmed in Australia on 26 th January and the number has 31 quickly increased with 2,423 confirmed cases as of 25 th March. 1 The rapidly rising number of people 32 experiencing ill health during a pandemic has the potential to have a detrimental impact on health 33 service delivery, particularly surrounding the provision of palliative care. 4 Within countries which 34 have comparable demographics to Australia, it is important that priority areas with significantly high 35 numbers of ageing people with disability and poor health service access are identified. Their 36 identification is a seminal first step towards evidence-based health service decisions. 37
Already, geographic information system (GIS) methods (hereafter described as spatial methods) have 38 been consistently employed towards monitoring and tracking the COVID-2019 pandemic. 5 Boulos 39

and Geraghty 5 detail how spatial methods have been essential towards the mapping of incidences of 40 COVID-19 globally. They also suggest that methods that can be useful to identify sites for new health 41 services. As an extension of this work, in the absence of resources and time to build new sites for 42 service delivery, such methods can identify where bespoke health service delivery modes -for 43 example, particular telehealth methods supporting palliative care for ageing people with disability 4 -44 should be delivered. 45

As a case-study to support future spatial work aimed at addressing service delivery for ageing people 46 with disability during a global pandemic, a spatial analysis was conducted to identify priority Melbourne metropolitan areas with a significantly high percentage and number of ageing adults (65+) 48 with disability, and high barriers to accessing primary health services. After, travel times from priority 49 areas to (i) palliative medicine, and (ii) hospital services were clarified.

Furthermore, including the perspectives of general 107 practitioners (GPs) with an expertise in palliative medicine for ageing people with disability within 108 telehealth sessions would be of benefit. Information sharing around how to manage the distinct 109 consequences of COVID-19 for ageing people with disability can ensure a tailored approach where 110 those who may not be able to receive inpatient health services due to service proximity and capacity 111 issues, are still able to receive adequate support via informed family members.
Spatial methods are increasingly becoming an essential method to inform health service planning. 123

However, in the realm of service provision for people with disability and ageing people, spatial 124 methods are seldom employed. 10 The case study provides a spatial method framework which can be 125 followed to identify priority areas for palliative care services in a time of crisis. Irrespective of 126 COVID-19, it expected that these methods have broader applications in ageing societies where 127 palliative care is increasingly becoming utilized. Coupling spatial methods with contextually 128 appropriate palliative care service offerings are essential towards the delivery of evidence-based, 129 effective palliative care.

To 61 identify areas with significantly high numbers and percentages of ageing people with disability, and 62 also poor access to primary health services, three Hot Spot Analyses using ESRI's ArcMap 10.4.1 63 were conducted. The Hot Spot (Getis-Ord Gi*) analysis identifies areas with significantly high and 64 low numbers of a domain given a geospatial mean. Similar to the approach undertaken by Lakhani et 65 al. 10 , areas which met the criteria of being significant (at the p<.05 level) during all three analyses 66 were identified as priority areas. After, a centroid (a marker representing the centre of an area) was 67 produced for each priority area, and the travel time via motor vehicle from priority areas to the nearest 68 palliative medicine and hospital service was clarified via two iterations of the origin destination cost 69 matrix geoprocessing tool. Finally, the travel time was averaged. 70 Findings 71 Out of 8910 areas, 2085 were identified as having a significantly high level of difficulty accessing 72 primary health services, 807 areas had a significantly high percentage of people with disability, while 73 664 had a significantly high number of people with disability. Thirty areas constituting areas of 74 priority were significant across all three domains. FIGREF2.text: , attention need be directed to distinct palliative care models that can support the health and 113 wellbeing of vulnerable populations in priority areas with poor access to health services during a 114 pandemic. Downar et al. 4 provide a palliative care pandemic plan which includes palliative care 115 considerations which are applicable. Their plan includes the domains 'stuff', 'staff', 'space' and 116 'systems'. In relation to the domain 'stuff', Donwar et al. 4 highlight the need for the adequate stock 117 and delivery of medicine and medical equipment relevant to the particular pandemic. Under the 118 context of COVID-19, an amendment to the 'stuff' component of their plan includes the potential use 119 of unmanned aerial technology (UAV) -as identified by Boulos and Geraghty 5 -to deliver medicine 120 and collect samples.121
